metadata.title: Differentially Private Testing of Identity and Closeness of Discrete Distributions
metadata.author: Jayadev Acharya, Ziteng Sun, Huanyu Zhang
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We study the fundamental problems of identity testing (goodness of fit), and closeness testing (two sample test) of distributions over k elements, under differential privacy. While the problems have a long history in statistics, finite sample bounds for these problems have only been established recently. In this work, we derive upper and lower bounds on the sample complexity of both the problems under (ε, δ)-differential privacy. We provide sample optimal algorithms for identity testing problem for all parameter ranges, and the first results for closeness testing. Our closeness testing bounds are optimal in the sparse regime where the number of samples is at most k. Our upper bounds are obtained by privatizing non-private estimators for these problems. The non-private estimators are chosen to have small sensitivity. We propose a general framework to establish lower bounds on the sample complexity of statistical tasks under differential privacy. We show a bound on differentially private algorithms in terms of a coupling between the two hypothesis classes we aim to test. By carefully constructing chosen priors over the hypothesis classes, and using Le Cam’s two point theorem we provide a general mechanism for proving lower bounds. We believe that the framework can be used to obtain strong lower bounds for other statistical tasks under privacy.

highlights: Testing whether observed data conforms to an underlying model is a fundamental scientific problem

In the past two decades there has been a lot of work from the computer science, information theory, and statistics community on various distribution testing problems in the non-asymptotic regime, where the domain size k could be potentially larger than m (See [13, 12, 37, 10, 49, 4, 3, 19, 26, 14, 18, 25, 11], references therein, and [17] for a recent survey)
The goal is to characterize the minimum number of samples necessary as a function of the domain size k, and the other parameters
Our bounds are optimal up to constant factors for all ranges of k, α, ε, δ, and for closeness testing the results are tight in the small sample regime where m = O(k)

One of the main contributions of our work is to propose a general framework for establishing lower bounds for the sample complexity of statistical problems such as property estimation and hypothesis testing under privacy constraints
In the sparse regime we prove a sample complexity bound of Θ
key_statements: Testing whether observed data conforms to an underlying model is a fundamental scientific problem

In the past two decades there has been a lot of work from the computer science, information theory, and statistics community on various distribution testing problems in the non-asymptotic regime, where the domain size k could be potentially larger than m (See [13, 12, 37, 10, 49, 4, 3, 19, 26, 14, 18, 25, 11], references therein, and [17] for a recent survey)
The goal is to characterize the minimum number of samples necessary as a function of the domain size k, and the other parameters
Our bounds are optimal up to constant factors for all ranges of k, α, ε, δ, and for closeness testing the results are tight in the small sample regime where m = O(k)

One of the main contributions of our work is to propose a general framework for establishing lower bounds for the sample complexity of statistical problems such as property estimation and hypothesis testing under privacy constraints
We reduce the problem of ε-differential privacy identity testing of distributions over [k] to ε-differential privacy uniformity testing over distributions over [6k]
In the sparse regime we prove a sample complexity bound of Θ
A general technique for proving lower bounds for differentially private algorithms is described in Section 3
We invoke LeCam’s two point theorem, and design a hypothesis testing problem that will imply a lower bound on uniformity testing
We describe the prior construction for Case 2, which is the same as considered by [49] for lower bounds on identity testing without privacy considerations
summary: Testing whether observed data conforms to an underlying model is a fundamental scientific problem.

One of the main contributions of our work is to propose a general framework for establishing lower bounds for the sample complexity of statistical problems such as property estimation and hypothesis testing under privacy constraints.
We establish a general method to prove lower bounds for distribution testing problems.
[42] use coupling to prove lower bounds on the sample complexity for differentially private confidence intervals.
Our results are more general, in that, we can handle mixtures of distributions, which can provide optimal lower bounds on identity testing.
[5] uses our coupling argument to prove lower bounds for differentially private property estimation problems.
Their results are sub-optimal for m = Ω(k) for identity testing, and they do not provide any lower bounds for the problems.
A general technique for proving lower bounds for differentially private algorithms is described in Section 3.
We would like to use coupling to prove lower bounds on differentially private algorithms for testing problems.
In the few sections, we use this theorem to get sample complexity bounds for differentially private testing problems.
In Theorem 3 we will show a reduction from identity to uniformity testing under pure differential privacy.
We will show that by privatizing the statistic proposed in [23] we can achieve the sample complexity in Theorem 2 for all parameter ranges.
To prove the sample complexity bound, we first show that the mean of the test statistic is well separated using Lemma 5.
We invoke LeCam’s two point theorem, and design a hypothesis testing problem that will imply a lower bound on uniformity testing.
We describe the prior construction for Case 2, which is the same as considered by [49] for lower bounds on identity testing without privacy considerations.
To obtain a sample complexity lower bound for distinguishing the two cases, we will design a coupling between Q1, and Q2, and bound its expected Hamming distance.
Recall the closeness testing problem from Section 2, and the tight non-private bounds from Table 1.
Our main result is the following theorem characterizing the sample complexity of differentially private algorithms for closeness testing.
We use the same approach with the test statistic as with uniformity testing to obtain a differentially private closeness testing method, described in Algorithm 2.
The remaining part is to show that Algorithm 2 satisfies sample complexity upper bounds described in theorem 4.
headline: We study the fundamental problems of identity testing , and closeness testing  of distributions over k elements, under differential privacy
